Entries.default: "I am busy, outsider."
The aumaua woman steps sideways, angling herself towards you, and meets your gaze with an intense stare.

"Do you come with the traders, brother? Or have the Kahanga chased you from Neketaka? You are not one of ours."

Her lip curls dismissively.
Entries.female:
"Do you come with the traders, sister? Or have the Kahanga chased you from Neketaka? You are not one of ours."

Her lip curls dismissively.

Entries.default:
"I do not know you."

Her voice is quiet, but each word is clipped and harsh.

"I did not think Clario's outsider to be one of Ngati's favored." 

Mokeha's voice is low and halting. Her rigid frown softens, and she folds her arms across her chest.

"Outsiders of every sort. This is what the Vailians have brought us."

Her scarred brow wrinkles, and her frown deepens into a somber grimace.
"I tire of this, outsider."
"Ekera, Outsider, you circle like a bird seeking scraps. What for do you trouble me?"
"I found this carving. I thought you might like it in exchange for Rinco's coin purse."

"What? Where did you find this?" 

She takes the carving from you, holding it with surprising care as she turns it over in her hands.
"What do you say?"
[Shrug.]
"Well, I didn't steal it. That's what really matters."
[Leave] "No reason."
"Rinco says that you robbed him during a card game."

"The Vailian? You jest, ekera. I should have thrown him into the sea.

"He dares to call me a thief?"
"What concern is this of one such as you? You have come a long way on the word of one fool."
"You are here for that skinny little Vailian?"
"Last warning. I won't go down as easily as Rinco."

"You come to our territory, under the elder's eye, to threaten us? 

"When you are dead, I will throw your carcass to the sharks."
"Why don't you tell me what really happened?"

"Ikawha told me I should see the tavern. Speak with their people. Learn patience. 

"The trader, Eofania, she taught me to play Vailian cards. A simple game- but none would play with me, in the tavern. Not until Rinco."
"Ekera, you even speak like your Vailian friends. Empty smiles and empty words."
[Lie] "I'm here under Governor Clario's authority."

"He sends you for this? The injured pride of a drunk?"

She laughs hoarsely.
"Clario has no say here. This is our village, and Ikawha's word is law."
[Leave] "I'll be back."
"About Rinco..."

"Hm. Then, here is what you came for, though it is an uneven trade."

She considers the coin purse in her hand for a moment, before handing it to you. Her mouth twists into a resentful frown.

"Him? I took what I was owed. You took more than that, I say. As I hear, he is dead. 

Now it is your governor's problem."

She turns away without another word.
"I fought the Vailian on his feet. But you slew him in his bed. You outsiders are mad."
"Thief! You will pay with your life!"
"You are looking for Ikawha?"
"I do not know you. What do you want?"
[Leave] "I'll be going."
With a quiet grunt and a final shake of the head, Mokeha turns away.
"I thought you might want to pick on someone your own size."
"I heard you like picking on people smaller than you."

"Rinco?"

She scoffs, in a guttural burst of sound.
Mokeha's facial markings only accentuate the downturned slant of her mouth. Her eyes narrow to dark slits, and she lowers her arms to her sides, fists clenching.

Mokeha blinks slowly, her stony expression unchanged.

After a few heartbeats, her frown deepens to an impressive scowl.

"The Vailian. He offers you coin, and you come to fight his battles for him." 

She spits onto the ground between you.
"I will tell that skinny little cheat to send the gold to your family."
Every trace of contemptuous amusement vanishes at once from Mokeha's face.
"By Ngati's light, spare me the attention of outsiders."
"Gutless thief. Take your trinkets, then. Do not think I will forget."
"This one killed the Storm Speaker! Do not let him escape!"
Entries.female: "This one killed the Storm Speaker! Do not let her escape!"

Entries.default: You hear a low, frustrated growl issue from Mokeha's throat.

"I will ask our chieftain to send a healer for that idiot Vailian.

"Perhaps that will quiet his whimpering."
"By Ngati, you tempt me to throw you in the sea."
"What for do you skulk around in the dark? Do you not sleep?"
"I thought him kind... until I proved the victor, and he grew angry. "Until he stood in front of his kin and called me- a Mataru of Sātahuzi- a 'filthy islander' and a cheat."
"For that, yes, I beat him. Why does this concern you?"
"So you admit to beating him."
"You should have told the guards. You've been branded a thief."
"I don't care who started it. Just give me the coin purse."
"Keep the coin purse. Rinco got what he deserved."
[Leave] "Let me talk to Rinco. I'll sort this out."
"I am no thief! Do you mean to insult me?"

"I am Mataru. I am the 'guard' in Sātahuzi. I defend this village. 

"If I see fit to punish a man, it is my duty."
"He'll be a long time recovering. Isn't that punishment enough?"

"Why should I yield to you, when I did not for Rinco and his kinsmen?

"If you wish to make a fight of it, I am ready."
[Attack] "So be it."
"Without that coin, Rinco will lose his home."
"Don't be foolish. Clario will see to him."
"That isn't how it works. The Vailians have to pay for their food, and pay taxes."
"Out there, the poor suffer at the hands of the wealthy. I've devoted my life to fighting that injustice."
"Rinco has a child to feed. It's not as if you need his money."

"Why did this not prevent him playing at cards in the first place? 

"Are all Vailians so mad for coin?"

"Here. Take it. I have no need for his Vailian coin." 

She hands you a small leather coin purse, and then turns to stride away without another word.

"In truth I do not have much use for it. Perhaps Ikawha will use the coin.

"...May Amira's winds blow sweet upon you, stranger."

"Blunt your teeth on this if you like. If he was a man of sense he would not be on his back."

She makes a dismissive, chopping gesture at the air, and turns away.
"Yes? And so? I say he earned worse, yet I was merciful."

"What else? The Vailians are fools. 

"But Ikawha wishes to trade, so we must be patient. We must save them from Ngati's storms, even when they ignore our advice."
"And yet he tells you that I have robbed him. He does not sound so humbled."

"Truly? I... did not expect this." 

Mokeha gives you a considering look.

"You see then, that it was just." 

She inclines her head. Her expression, when she rises again, is one of relief.
"If a Vailian broke Huana law, would you be satisfied with a fine levied by the governor?"
"...So, then. What am I to do? I did not wish him dead."
[Attack] "I challenge you on Rinco's behalf."
"Give me the coin purse, and we'll call it square."
"I think people usually apologize for this sort of thing."

"His kinsmen would let him starve?" 

Mokeha's brows furrow, and her eyes search your face.
"I have heard stories. I thought they must be falsehoods, grown large in the recounting."
"I really don't."
Mokeha snorts, and folds her arms. Her fingers tap impatiently against her armor.
"Rinco's just a merchant. He can't fight you as an equal."
Mokeha opens her mouth to speak... then snaps it shut. She grimaces, averting her gaze to the sand.

"I did not consider this. He is Kuaru- it is not in him to fight for the village.

"...Perhaps I was impatient."

"That... that is not the same. This has long been our island."

Mokeha scowls at you.
"If you say so."

Mokeha nods slowly, her expression pleased.

She rolls her shoulders, and settles into a fighting stance.

"I will not. 

"...But I will ask Ikawha to send a healer. Perhaps that will quiet his whimpering."
"You are looking for Ikawha?"
